entries.summary: Architecture patterns for SAP MDG / MDM programs covering Create, Update, Migration/Cutover, and Day-2 operations.

entries.summary: Translate breached metrics into deterministic governance actions via linked Decision Blocks.

entries.title: Mdg Metrics Framework V0 1
entries.summary: Provide a canonical, AI-readable metrics framework for MDG governance: detect drift, assess decision quality, and trigger the right Decision Blocks.

entries.title: Mdg Tool Pack V0 1
entries.summary: A minimal practical toolkit to operationalize the MDG Governance Reasoning Framework (Decision Blocks + Metrics + Playbooks) for real projects and AI/RAG usage.

entries.title: Context Engineering is a Discipline, Not a Prompt Trick
entries.summary: Context Engineering is a Discipline, Not a Prompt Trick

entries.title: Positional Strategy: Engineering Around 'Lost in the Middle' in Long Context + RAG
entries.summary: Positional Strategy: Engineering Around 'Lost in the Middle' in Long Context + RAG

entries.title: Retrieval as a Product: RAG Refinement, Compression, and Long-Context Noise Control
entries.summary: Retrieval as a Product: RAG Refinement, Compression, and Long-Context Noise Control

entries.title: Prompt Optimization as Engineering: From Handcrafted Prompts to Optimized Systems
entries.summary: Prompt Optimization as Engineering: From Handcrafted Prompts to Optimized Systems

entries.title: Segmentation
entries.summary: Reduce system rigidity by dividing a problem into independently changeable parts.

entries.title: Taking Out (Separation)
entries.summary: Remove or isolate a problematic or volatile part so the rest of the system can stay stable and simple.

entries.title: Local Quality
entries.summary: Allow different parts of a system to have different properties instead of forcing uniformity everywhere.

entries.title: Asymmetry
entries.summary: Break false symmetry to reduce complexity, cost, or risk by assigning different roles or properties to similar-looking parts.

entries.title: Merging
entries.summary: Reduce overhead and latency by combining related elements, activities, or responsibilities when separation creates friction.

entries.title: Universality
entries.summary: Reduce system complexity by making one element perform multiple functions instead of introducing new specialized components.

entries.title: Nested Doll
entries.summary: Manage complexity by placing systems or components inside others, creating clear containment and layered responsibility.

entries.title: Anti-Weight (Counterbalance)
entries.summary: Offset negative forces or constraints by introducing compensating mechanisms instead of fighting them directly.

entries.title: Preliminary Anti-Action
entries.summary: Reduce risk and cost by performing preventive actions before a problem fully manifests.

entries.title: Preliminary Action
entries.summary: Accelerate execution by preparing critical elements in advance so the main action becomes simple and fast.

entries.title: Beforehand Cushioning
entries.summary: Absorb shocks and uncertainty by building safety buffers into the system before failures occur.

entries.title: Equipotentiality
entries.summary: Reduce unnecessary effort by aligning conditions so work does not have to fight against artificial differences.

entries.title: The Other Way Around (Inversion)
entries.summary: Solve a problem by reversing actions, relationships, or assumptions instead of optimizing the existing direction.

entries.title: Spheroidality / Curvature
entries.summary: Increase adaptability and robustness by replacing rigid, linear structures with flexible, curved, or adaptive ones.

entries.title: Dynamics
entries.summary: Allow a system to change its structure, behavior, or parameters over time instead of remaining static.

entries.title: Partial or Excessive Actions
entries.summary: Achieve better results by deliberately doing less or more than the nominal requirement instead of aiming for exactness.

entries.title: Another Dimension
entries.summary: Unlock new solution space by moving the problem into an additional dimension instead of optimizing within the same plane.

entries.title: Mechanical Vibration
entries.summary: Improve performance by introducing controlled oscillation, iteration, or repetition instead of static operation.

entries.title: Periodic Action
entries.summary: Replace continuous or one-time actions with periodic ones to reduce load, cost, and risk while maintaining effectiveness.

entries.title: Continuity of Useful Action
entries.summary: Maximize value creation by ensuring the system is always performing useful work instead of waiting or idling.

entries.title: Skipping (Rushing Through)
entries.summary: Reduce negative effects or inefficiencies by executing certain steps very quickly or bypassing them when their duration adds no value.

entries.title: Blessing in Disguise
entries.summary: Turn a harmful effect or constraint into a useful feature instead of eliminating it.

entries.title: Feedback
entries.summary: Improve control and outcomes by continuously feeding results back into the system to adjust behavior.

entries.title: Intermediary
entries.summary: Reduce coupling and conflict by introducing an intermediate element that manages interaction between parts.

entries.title: Self-Service
entries.summary: Reduce coordination cost and delays by letting a system or user perform needed actions independently.

entries.title: Copying
entries.summary: Reduce cost, risk, or complexity by using copies, templates, or simplified representations instead of originals.

entries.title: Cheap Short-Living Objects
entries.summary: Reduce risk and cost by using temporary, disposable, or easily replaceable elements instead of durable ones.

entries.title: Mechanics Substitution
entries.summary: Replace rigid, manual, or mechanical approaches with more flexible, informational, or automated ones.

entries.title: Pneumatics and Hydraulics
entries.summary: Transmit force, control, or influence indirectly through flexible, buffered media instead of rigid connections.

entries.title: Flexible Shells and Thin Films
entries.summary: Protect core elements while keeping the system lightweight and adaptable by adding flexible, minimal protective layers.

entries.title: Porous Materials
entries.summary: Increase adaptability and resilience by allowing controlled permeability instead of enforcing total isolation.

entries.title: Color Changes
entries.summary: Improve understanding, control, and reaction speed by making system states and risks immediately visible.

entries.title: Homogeneity
entries.summary: Reduce friction and complexity by making interacting elements similar in nature, structure, or rules.

entries.title: Discarding and Recovering
entries.summary: Improve flow and resilience by intentionally removing elements when they are no longer useful, while keeping the ability to restore them if needed.

entries.title: Parameter Changes
entries.summary: Improve outcomes by changing key parameters instead of redesigning the entire system.

entries.title: Phase Transitions
entries.summary: Achieve step-change improvements by moving the system into a different operating state instead of incremental optimization.

entries.title: Thermal Expansion
entries.summary: Exploit expansion, contraction, or elasticity effects to adapt to changing conditions without redesign.

entries.title: Strong Oxidants
entries.summary: Achieve radical improvement by introducing a more powerful, transformative mechanism instead of incremental enhancement.

entries.title: Inert Atmosphere
entries.summary: Stabilize sensitive operations by isolating them from disruptive external influences.

entries.title: Composite Materials
entries.summary: Combine different elements to achieve properties that none of them provide alone.

entries.title: Contradiction Formulation (Engineering Contradiction)
entries.summary: Turn a messy situation into a solvable TRIZ problem by expressing it as a trade-off between two parameters.

entries.title: Physical Contradiction + Separation Principles
entries.summary: Break a deadlock where the same parameter must be simultaneously high and low by separating requirements across conditions.

entries.title: System Operator (9 Windows)
entries.summary: Escape tunnel vision by analyzing the problem across time (past/present/future) and hierarchy (subsystem/system/supersystem).

entries.title: X-Operator (Exaggeration / Extremes)
entries.summary: Force breakthrough ideas by pushing a system parameter to an extreme and observing what must change to make it work.

entries.title: TRIZ Byte Template
entries.summary: TRIZ Byte Template

entries.title: The Agent Loop: Observe → Plan → Act → Verify
entries.summary: Understand the minimal mental model of an AI agent so you can explain it clearly and design it reliably.

entries.title: Tools vs Chat: When an Agent Must Act, Not Just Talk
entries.summary: Learn to clearly distinguish between 'thinking in text' and 'acting on the world', and explain why serious agents must use tools.

entries.title: Output Contracts: Why Agents Must Speak JSON
entries.summary: Understand why strict output formats (JSON schemas) are critical for building agents you can trust, debug, and automate.

entries.title: Chunking: How Knowledge Must Be Cut for RAG
entries.summary: Learn how to structure knowledge so an agent can reliably retrieve and use it without confusion or hallucination.

entries.title: Metadata: Teaching Agents What a Chunk Is About
entries.summary: Understand how metadata turns raw text chunks into navigable, filterable, and trustworthy knowledge for agents.

entries.title: Reranking: Choosing the Right Knowledge After Retrieval
entries.summary: Understand why initial retrieval is not enough and how reranking helps an agent select the most relevant and safe knowledge.

entries.title: Guardrails: What an Agent Is Never Allowed to Do
entries.summary: Learn how to define hard boundaries so an agent behaves safely, predictably, and does not overstep its authority.

entries.title: Self-Check / Critic: Teaching Agents to Verify Themselves
entries.summary: Understand how to add an explicit self-check step so agents catch their own mistakes before users do.

entries.title: Plan → Execute: Separating Thinking from Doing
entries.summary: Learn why agents must separate planning from execution to stay controllable, debuggable, and safe.

entries.title: Human-in-the-Loop: Where Agents Must Stop and Ask
entries.summary: Understand where and why an agent must defer to a human, and how to design clear handoff points.

entries.title: Golden Set & Evals: How to Know Your Agent Works
entries.summary: Learn how to evaluate agents systematically so improvements do not break existing behavior.

entries.title: Tracing & Observability: Making Agent Behavior Explainable
entries.summary: Understand how to trace, inspect, and explain what an agent did, step by step, in production.

entries.title: Memory: What Agents Should Remember (and Forget)
entries.summary: Understand different types of agent memory and how to use them without creating confusion, drift, or privacy risks.

entries.title: Prompt Injection & RAG Defense: How Agents Protect Themselves
entries.summary: Learn how to prevent agents from being manipulated by user input or retrieved content, especially in RAG systems.

entries.title: Cost & Latency Budgeting: Designing Agents That Are Economical
entries.summary: Understand how to design agents with predictable cost and latency, so they are usable at scale and acceptable for business.

entries.title: Versioning: How Agents and Knowledge Evolve Safely
entries.summary: Learn how to change agents, prompts, and knowledge without breaking existing behavior or trust.

entries.title: Failure Modes & Fallbacks: What Agents Do When Things Go Wrong
entries.summary: Understand the most common ways agents fail in production and how to design explicit fallback strategies instead of silent breakdowns.

entries.title: Single-Agent vs Multi-Agent: When One Brain Is Enough
entries.summary: Understand when a single agent is sufficient and when splitting responsibilities across multiple agents makes systems more reliable and maintainable.

entries.title: Agent Interfaces & Contracts: How Agents Communicate Safely
entries.summary: Understand how agents should communicate with other agents and systems using strict contracts instead of free text.

entries.title: Ownership, SLAs & Accountability: Who Is Responsible for the Agent
entries.summary: Understand how to assign clear ownership and service expectations so agents can be operated like real systems, not experiments.

entries.title: Business Value: Where Agents Create Real Impact (and Where They Don’t)
entries.summary: Learn to identify use cases where agents generate measurable business value, and avoid areas where they add complexity without payoff.

entries.title: From Bytes to RAG: Assembling an Agent Knowledge Base
entries.summary: Learn how to turn individual bytes into a coherent RAG knowledge base that agents can reliably use in production.

entries.title: Owning the Knowledge: Turning Bytes into a Personal Moat
entries.summary: Understand how structured agentic bytes become a long-term personal asset you can explain, reuse, sell, and build products on.

entries.title: Chat-First AMS: One Conversation, One Trace
entries.summary: Stop treating support like email archaeology. Run AMS through structured chats that automatically produce the evidence trail.

entries.title: Metrics That Hurt (in a Good Way)
entries.summary: If your metrics don’t change behavior, they are decorative. Modern AMS uses indicators that expose waste, risk, and fake progress.

entries.title: Stable SAP Core, Free Edges
entries.summary: The mistake is not SAP itself. The mistake is letting SAP define how expensive, slow, and locked-in your whole landscape becomes.

entries.title: No Fiori Dependency: AMS Runs on Signals, Not Screens
entries.summary: User interfaces age fast. Signals, events, and data contracts age slowly. AMS should operate on the latter.

entries.title: Don’t Carry Problems Forward: SAP AMS as a Load-Killing System
entries.summary: Old AMS accumulates pain and calls it backlog. Modern SAP AMS deletes load permanently.

entries.title: Contain Custom Code: Stop Z-Code from Owning AMS
entries.summary: Most SAP AMS pain is not caused by SAP standard. It’s caused by unmanaged custom code quietly becoming critical infrastructure.

entries.title: Standard Changes, Automated Execution
entries.summary: Speed in SAP AMS doesn’t come from shortcuts. It comes from removing choice where choice is unnecessary.

entries.title: AI-Augmented Diagnosis: Faster Thinking, Fewer Guess Cycles
entries.summary: SAP incidents are rarely hard because they are complex. They are hard because diagnosis starts blind.

entries.title: Choose What NOT to Fix: Data-Driven AMS Triage
entries.summary: If you try to fix everything in SAP, you end up fixing nothing well. Modern AMS is ruthless about priority — using data, not эмоции.

entries.title: AMS Contracts That Don’t Lie: SLAs, SLOs, and Penalties With Teeth
entries.summary: Classic SAP AMS uses SLAs like makeup. Modern AMS uses measurable reliability targets tied to business flows — and penalties that punish the right behavior.

entries.title: Team Topology for SAP AMS: Fewer Handovers, Faster Fixes
entries.summary: Most SAP AMS slowness is not technical. It’s organizational latency: handovers, unclear ownership, and ‘not my module’.

entries.title: Approval Without Paralysis: Decision Gates That Actually Work
entries.summary: Approvals are not control. They are latency. Real control comes from clear gates, data, and reversible decisions.

entries.title: Coordination Without Noise: How SAP AMS Talks Under Pressure
entries.summary: Most outages get worse because communication collapses. Too many messages, no shared truth, and zero decision rhythm.

entries.title: Incentives That Shape Behavior: Teams, Bonuses, and Penalties
entries.summary: You get the AMS you pay for. If incentives reward speed and silence, you’ll get fragile fixes and hidden problems.

entries.title: Vendor and Internal Team Alignment: One System, Not a Battlefield
entries.summary: SAP AMS fails fastest when internal IT, vendors, and business optimize against each other instead of the system.

entries.title: Risk, Audit, and Control Without Slowing the System
entries.summary: Audit pressure usually makes SAP AMS slower and more defensive. Done right, it actually makes it calmer and cheaper.

entries.title: Upgrade and Release Insulation: Keep AMS Calm While SAP Changes
entries.summary: SAP releases don’t kill AMS. What kills AMS is when every upgrade becomes a surprise generator.

entries.title: Training That Pays Back: SAP AMS Enablement as a Ticket-Killer
entries.summary: Most AMS training is a one-off slideshow. Modern AMS training is a system that steadily deletes recurring demand.

entries.title: Handover Without Amnesia: Make Knowledge Survive People
entries.summary: AMS collapses not when systems change, but when people change. Bad handovers recreate the same incidents with new names.

entries.title: Knowledge Base as an Engine: Built for RAG, Not for Reading
entries.summary: A classic SAP KB is dead text. A modern AMS knowledge base is an execution engine for humans, bots, and AI.

entries.title: Ideas Pipeline: Turning SAP AMS Pain into Improvements
entries.summary: Good ideas don’t appear in workshops. They leak out of incidents, workarounds, and repeated frustration — if you know how to capture them.

entries.title: Continuous Learning Loop: AMS That Gets Smarter Every Month
entries.summary: If AMS knowledge doesn’t compound, you’re paying forever for the same lessons.

entries.title: Exit Without Shock: AMS as a Controlled SAP Lock-In Reducer
entries.summary: You don’t escape SAP by rewriting it. You escape SAP by slowly making it less central — without breaking the business.

entries.title: AMS as a Platform: Agents, Open Stack, and Composable Ops
entries.summary: When AMS stays a process, it caps its value. When AMS becomes a platform, it compounds.

entries.title: Security and SoD as a First-Class AMS Flow
entries.summary: In classic SAP AMS, security is a gate at the end. In modern AMS, security is a continuous flow that prevents incidents instead of reacting to them.

entries.title: Effort Estimation That Doesn’t Lie: Size, Risk, and Coordination Cost
entries.summary: In SAP AMS, bad estimates don’t just miss deadlines — they create chaos: wrong priorities, broken approvals, and hidden risk.

entries.title: Problem vs Change Portfolio: Stop Letting Changes Starve Prevention
entries.summary: SAP AMS usually drowns not because of too many incidents, but because Problems and Changes fight for the same oxygen — and Problems always lose.

entries.title: Backlog Hygiene: Keep SAP AMS Clean or It Will Rot
entries.summary: A dirty backlog is silent technical debt. It consumes attention, hides priorities, and creates fake urgency.

entries.title: Boards and Scorecards: Executive Visibility Without Theater
entries.summary: Most AMS reporting is designed to look busy. Modern AMS boards are designed to force decisions.

entries.title: Handover & Transition at Scale: Zero-Drama AMS Transfers
entries.summary: Most AMS transitions fail quietly. Not on day one — three months later, when the same incidents return and nobody remembers why.

entries.title: Crisis Mode (P0): Lead the System, Not the Noise
entries.summary: In a real SAP P0, technical skill matters less than control of flow, attention, and decisions.

entries.title: Financial Transparency: Know Where AMS Money Actually Goes
entries.summary: If you can’t explain why AMS costs what it costs, you can’t reduce it without breaking something important.

entries.title: Demand Forecasting & Capacity Planning: Stop Scheduling Surprises
entries.summary: SAP AMS feels ‘overloaded’ when demand is unmanaged and capacity is planned as if tomorrow will be like yesterday.

entries.title: AMS as a Product: Roadmap, Value Promises, and ‘Stop Doing’ Lists
entries.summary: If SAP AMS is treated as a service desk, it stays expensive forever. If it’s treated as a product, it becomes predictable, improvable, and cheaper over time.

entries.title: Master Data in AMS: Treat Data Quality as Production Reliability
entries.summary: In SAP, master data is not ‘data’. It’s executable configuration. Bad data behaves like bad code — it breaks flows, creates incidents, and burns AMS capacity.

entries.title: Change Intake & Agreement: Stop Negotiating Chaos
entries.summary: Most SAP AMS pain starts before any work begins — at intake. Vague requests turn into scope creep, rework, and unsafe changes.

entries.title: Conflict-Proof AMS: Multi-Vendor Reality Without Blame Games
entries.summary: Conflicts in SAP AMS don’t come from bad people. They come from unclear boundaries, mixed incentives, and missing evidence.

entries.title: Verification & Acceptance: Prove the Change Worked (or Don’t Close It)
entries.summary: Most SAP AMS work fails quietly at the end: changes are ‘done’, but nobody can prove the business is safer or faster.

entries.title: Knowledge → Automation → Agent Loop: Make Fixes Compound
entries.summary: If a fix lives only in a human’s head, AMS pays for it forever. Modern AMS turns fixes into reusable assets.

entries.title: AMS Culture Rules: Behavior That Makes the System Work
entries.summary: Processes don’t fail first in SAP AMS. Behavior does. Culture is the invisible control plane.

entries.title: AMS Operating System: How All Pieces Work as One
entries.summary: Modern SAP AMS fails when parts are optimized in isolation. It succeeds when everything is wired into a single operating system.

entries.title: Executive One-Pager: Modern SAP AMS in 5 Minutes
entries.summary: This AMS is designed to reduce risk and cost at the same time — without betting the business on big rewrites.

entries.title: Anti-Patterns Catalog: What Kills SAP AMS Faster Than Bugs
entries.summary: Most AMS disasters are not caused by SAP defects. They are caused by repeated bad patterns that everyone quietly tolerates.

entries.title: From Support to Trusted Advisor: Introducing New Capabilities Without Noise
entries.summary: New SAP or adjacent capabilities fail not because they are bad, but because AMS introduces them like features — instead of decisions.

entries.title: Vendor Segmentation & Operating Boundaries: How to Run Multi-Vendor AMS Cleanly
entries.summary: Multi-vendor AMS only works when boundaries are real: defined surfaces, measurable contracts, controlled access, and a single arbitration layer.

entries.title: Decision Support Factory: Making Reliable Estimates for Business Choices
entries.summary: The fastest way to become a trusted AMS provider is to stop answering with opinions — and start delivering decision packs that survive scrutiny.

entries.title: AMS Maturity Levels: From Firefighting to Decision Platform
entries.summary: Most SAP AMS teams believe they are mature because systems are running. Real maturity starts when the system improves itself.

entries.title: AMS Reputation Metrics: Measuring Trust, Not Ticket Volume
entries.summary: Reputation in AMS is not what people say in meetings. It’s what they do before problems appear.

entries.title: AMS as Risk Buffer: Absorbing Business Uncertainty Without Breaking SAP
entries.summary: SAP breaks not because change exists, but because risk is unmanaged. Modern AMS exists to absorb uncertainty — not to pretend it isn’t there.

entries.title: RAG-First Documentation: From Diagrams to Living Text Structures
entries.summary: Classic SAP documentation dies the moment reality changes. Diagrams freeze assumptions. Text structures evolve.

entries.title: TCO & ROI in Modern AMS: Measuring What Actually Matters
entries.summary: AMS cost is not what you pay the vendor. It’s what the system forces you to repeat.
